items.title: News Wrap: Trump orders troops to Portland, authorizing ‘full force’
items.standfirst: In our news wrap Saturday, Trump says he’s sending troops to Portland to protect it from what he called “domestic terrorists,” the Trump administration asked the Supreme Court to uphold restrictions the president wants to impose on birthright citizenship, and nearly 60 people were killed in Gaza…

items.content: The president says the latest move is "necessary" to protect immigration detention facilities in the major US city.

items.title: Trump orders deployment of troops to US city of Portland and ICE facilities
items.standfirst: The city's Democratic mayor says there is no need for the US president to send federal forces.
items.content: The city's Democratic mayor says there is no need for the US president to send federal forces.

items.title: Trump authorises ‘full force’ as he orders troops to ‘war-ravaged’ Portland
items.standfirst: Move to protect immigration enforcement facilities is fourth deployment in Democrat-controlled US cities
items.content: Move to protect immigration enforcement facilities is fourth deployment in Democrat-controlled US cities

items.title: Donald Trump says he is deploying troops to Portland, Oregon
items.standfirst: Apparently misled by hyperbolic reporting from conservative outlets on a single small protest, president described peaceful city as ‘war ravaged’Donald Trump said on Saturday he is deploying troops to Portland, Oregon, “authorizing Full Force, if necessary”, ignoring pleas from local officials and the state’s congressional delegation, who suggested that the president was misinformed or lying about the nature and scale of a single, small protest outside one federal immigration enforcement office.Trump made the announcement on social media, where he claimed that the deployment was necessary “to protect War ravaged Portland,” and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice) facilities he said were “under siege by antifascists “and other domestic terrorists”. Continue reading...
items.content: Apparently misled by hyperbolic reporting from conservative outlets on a single small protest, president described peaceful city as ‘war ravaged’Donald Trump said on Saturday he is deploying troops to Portland, Oregon, “authorizing Full Force, if necessary”, ignoring pleas from local officials and the state’s congressional delegation, who suggested that the president was misinformed or lying about the nature and scale of a single, small protest outside one federal immigration enforcement office.Trump made the announcement on social media, where he claimed that the deployment was necessary “to protect War ravaged Portland,” and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice) facilities he said were “under siege by antifascists “and other domestic terrorists”. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump announces deployment of federal troops to Portland, Oregon to handle ‘domestic terrorists’
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump on Saturday said he was authorizing the deployment of federal troops to Portland, Oregon, which he described as “under siege from attack by Antifa, and other domestic terrorists”. Portland is the latest city targeted by the Trump administration for deployments following announcements regarding Chicago, Memphis, Washington, DC and Los Angeles.
items.content: US President Donald Trump on Saturday said he was authorizing the deployment of federal troops to Portland, Oregon, which he described as “under siege from attack by Antifa, and other domestic terrorists”. Portland is the latest city targeted by the Trump administration for deployments following announcements regarding Chicago, Memphis, Washington, DC and Los Angeles.

ai_summary: Trump ordered troops to Portland, Oregon, to protect ICE facilities, according to his post.
The Supreme Court is asked to uphold Trump's restrictions on birthright citizenship.
Trump authorized "full force" in Portland, citing domestic terrorists as the threat.
The administration is seeking to limit birthright citizenship, challenging the 14th Amendment.
Reports indicate troops will be deployed to Portland to protect immigration detention facilities.

clusters.title: Sanctions reimposed on Iran 10 years after landmark nuclear deal

items.title: Sanctions reimposed on Iran 10 years after landmark nuclear deal

items.content: Iran says the sanctions are "unjust" and "illegal" and has urged countries not to implement them.

items.title: UN imposes 'snapback' sanctions on a hungrier, poorer and more anxious Iran
items.standfirst: The United Nations reimposed sanctions on Iran early Sunday over its nuclear program, further squeezing the Islamic Republic as its people increasingly find themselves priced out of the food they need to survive and worried about their futures.
items.content: The United Nations reimposed sanctions on Iran early Sunday over its nuclear program, further squeezing the Islamic Republic as its people increasingly find themselves priced out of the food they need to survive and worried about their futures.(Image credit: Vahid Salemi)

items.title: UN reimposes sanctions on Iran over accusations it violated nuclear deal
items.standfirst: The United Nations has reimposed sanctions on Iran over accusations that the country violated a nuclear deal.
items.content: The United Nations has reimposed sanctions on Iran over accusations that the country violated a nuclear deal.

items.title: UN reimposes Iran sanctions over its nuclear program
items.standfirst: The United Nations reimposed its sanctions on Iran because of its "significant non-performance" of nuclear commitments after initiating the snapback process on August 28, according to the United State...
items.content: The United Nations reimposed its sanctions on Iran because of its "significant non-performance" of nuclear commitments after initiating the snapback process on August 28, according to the United State...

items.title: Iran slams ‘illegal’ vote as UN reimposes decade-old sanctions
items.standfirst: The UN has reimposed sanctions on Iran, a decade after they were lifted as part of the nuclear deal called the JCPOA.
items.content: The UN has reimposed sanctions on Iran, a decade after they were lifted as part of the nuclear deal called the JCPOA.

ai_summary: The UN reimposed sanctions on Iran due to its nuclear program non-performance.
Iran calls the sanctions "unjust" and urges countries not to implement them.
Sanctions were reimposed after the "snapback" process initiated on August 28.
The sanctions further squeeze Iran, impacting food availability and economic stability.
The UN action comes a decade after sanctions were lifted as part of the JCPOA.

clusters.title: ‘Hundreds’ of Russian missiles and drones hit Ukraine in deadly strikes as Poland scrambles jets
clusters.neutral_headline: Russia Launches Major Drone, Missile Attack on Ukraine

items.title: ‘Hundreds’ of Russian missiles and drones hit Ukraine in deadly strikes as Poland scrambles jets
items.standfirst: At least four people were killed in the overnight attacks on Kyiv and other regions as Poland takes preventive measure to secure airspaceRussian strikes involving “hundreds” of drones and missiles have killed at least four people, including a 12-year-old girl, and wounded at least 10 people in Ukraine on Sunday, as Poland scrambled fighter jets to secure its airspace.An air raid alert was in place over the Kyiv region, with the local military administration saying Russia was attacking with drones and missiles. Continue reading...
items.content: At least four people were killed in the overnight attacks on Kyiv and other regions as Poland takes preventive measure to secure airspaceRussian strikes involving “hundreds” of drones and missiles have killed at least four people, including a 12-year-old girl, and wounded at least 10 people in Ukraine on Sunday, as Poland scrambled fighter jets to secure its airspace.An air raid alert was in place over the Kyiv region, with the local military administration saying Russia was attacking with drones and missiles. Continue reading...

items.title: Russia launches major drone and missile attack on Ukraine, killing at least 4
items.standfirst: Russia pounded Ukraine with "hundreds" of drones and missiles overnight, wounding at least 10 people and killing four, including a 12-year-old girl. The attacks came after Russia warned NATO against taking sterner action in response to alleged incursions into airspace covered by the military alliance.
items.content: Russia pounded Ukraine with "hundreds" of drones and missiles overnight, wounding at least 10 people and killing four, including a 12-year-old girl. The attacks came after Russia warned NATO against taking sterner action in response to alleged incursions into airspace covered by the military alliance.

items.title: At least 4 killed in major Russian drone, missile attack on Ukraine’s Kyiv
items.standfirst: Media reports and independent monitor describe the latest strikes on Ukraine as 'one of the heaviest' since war began.
items.content: Media reports and independent monitor describe the latest strikes on Ukraine as 'one of the heaviest' since war began.

items.title: Kyiv Comes Under Another Massive Drone and Missile Attack
Russia launches massive attack on Kyiv - as Poland scrambles jets and closes airspace
items.standfirst: Russia has launched a massive drone and missile attack on Ukraine's capital this morning, killing four people and injuring about 10, Kyiv's military administration has said.
items.content: Russia has launched a massive drone and missile attack on Ukraine's capital this morning, killing four people and injuring about 10, Kyiv's military administration has said.

items.title: Russian launches major drone, missile attack on Ukraine, still ongoing

ai_summary: Russia launched a major drone and missile attack on Kyiv and other regions.
The attacks killed at least four people, including a 12-year-old girl.
Poland scrambled jets to secure its airspace during the attacks.
The strikes are described as "one of the heaviest" since the war began.
The attacks followed warnings to NATO against further action in Ukraine.

items.title: Moldovans cast ballots in a tense election plagued by Russian interference claims
items.standfirst: Moldovans are heading to the polls to cast ballots in a tense parliamentary election plagued by claims of Russian interference
items.content: Moldovans are heading to the polls to cast ballots in a tense parliamentary election plagued by claims of Russian interference

items.title: Polls open in critical Moldova election plagued with Russian interference claims
items.standfirst: Polls opened in Moldova on Sunday in parliamentary elections that could see the country swerve from its pro-European path towards Moscow, with the government and the EU accusing Russia of "deeply interfering". The results of the critical election are expected later on Sunday.
items.content: Polls opened in Moldova on Sunday in parliamentary elections that could see the country swerve from its pro-European path towards Moscow, with the government and the EU accusing Russia of "deeply interfering". The results of the critical election are expected later on Sunday.

items.title: Moldova heads to the polls in tense vote that could steer country closer to EU or Russia
items.standfirst: President Maia Sandu says parliamentary vote is Moldova’s ‘most consequential election’ and warns against falling deeper into Moscow’s orbitMoldovans began voting on Sunday in parliamentary elections that could see the country neighbouring Ukraine swerve from its pro-European path towards Moscow, with the government and the EU accusing Russia of “deeply interfering”.Moldova, an EU candidate country, has long been divided over closer ties with Brussels or maintaining Soviet-era relations with Moscow. Continue reading...
items.content: President Maia Sandu says parliamentary vote is Moldova’s ‘most consequential election’ and warns against falling deeper into Moscow’s orbitMoldovans began voting on Sunday in parliamentary elections that could see the country neighbouring Ukraine swerve from its pro-European path towards Moscow, with the government and the EU accusing Russia of “deeply interfering”.Moldova, an EU candidate country, has long been divided over closer ties with Brussels or maintaining Soviet-era relations with Moscow. Continue reading...

items.title: Moldova bars pro-Russian party from tense parliamentary election
items.standfirst: Moldova’s electoral commission barred a pro-Russian party from participating in this weekend's tense parliamentary election, which is beleaguered by widespread claims of Russian interference. The vote could decide the country’s geopolitical future: a stark choice between East and West. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondent Maria Gerth-Niculescu.
items.content: Moldova’s electoral commission barred a pro-Russian party from participating in this weekend's tense parliamentary election, which is beleaguered by widespread claims of Russian interference. The vote could decide the country’s geopolitical future: a stark choice between East and West. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondent Maria Gerth-Niculescu.

items.title: Moldova holds key election as Russia's shadow looms large
items.standfirst: The country has accused Moscow of election interference on an unprecedented scale.
items.content: The country has accused Moscow of election interference on an unprecedented scale.

ai_summary: Moldova held parliamentary elections with claims of Russian interference.
The governing pro-EU party is projected to be in the lead, according to polls.
The election could shift Moldova's path towards the EU or Moscow.
The EU and the government accuse Russia of "deeply interfering" in the election.
A pro-Russian party was barred from participating in the election.

items.content: Tens of thousands had gathered at a campaign event for actor-turned-politician Vijay in India's southern state of Tamil Nadu.

items.content: Vijay, a well-known actor who goes by only one name, launched a political party last year.

items.content: At least 36 people have been killed and dozens injured during a stampede at a campaign rally for actor-turned-politician Vijay - a huge star in the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu.

ai_summary: A stampede at a rally for actor Vijay in Tamil Nadu, India, occurred.
At least 36 people died, and over 50 were injured in the stampede.
The victims included eight children who died before reaching the hospital.
Vijay, a popular actor, launched a political party last year.
Tens of thousands gathered at the campaign event in southern India.

items.title: US to revoke Colombian president's visa over comments at pro-Palestinian gathering
items.standfirst: The United States said it would revoke Colombian President Gustavo Petro's visa after he took to New York's streets on Friday in a pro-Palestinian demonstration and urged US soldiers to disobey President Donald Trump's orders. Story by Shirli Sitbon.
items.content: The United States said it would revoke Colombian President Gustavo Petro's visa after he took to New York's streets on Friday in a pro-Palestinian demonstration and urged US soldiers to disobey President Donald Trump's orders. Story by Shirli Sitbon.

items.standfirst: Gustavo Petro told US soldiers to "disobey Trump's orders" while addressing a protest in New York.
items.content: Gustavo Petro told US soldiers to "disobey Trump's orders" while addressing a protest in New York.

items.title: US revokes Colombian president's visa after he urges troops to disobey Trump's orders
items.standfirst: The US has said it will cancel the visa of the President of Colombia after he urged US troops to disobey Donald Trump's orders.
items.content: The US has said it will cancel the visa of the President of Colombia after he urged US troops to disobey Donald Trump's orders.

items.title: US revokes visa for Colombian president Gustavo Petro after ‘reckless’ actions in New York
items.standfirst: At a pro-Palestine protest, Petro urged US soldiers to ‘disobey Trump’s order’ and ‘not point their rifles at humanity’The US state department said on Friday it would revoke the visa of Colombian leftist president Gustavo Petro for his “incendiary actions” during a pro-Palestinian street protest in New York.“Earlier today, Colombian president @petrogustavo stood on a NYC street and urged US soldiers to disobey orders and incite violence,” the state department said on X. Continue reading...
items.content: At a pro-Palestine protest, Petro urged US soldiers to ‘disobey Trump’s order’ and ‘not point their rifles at humanity’The US state department said on Friday it would revoke the visa of Colombian leftist president Gustavo Petro for his “incendiary actions” during a pro-Palestinian street protest in New York.“Earlier today, Colombian president @petrogustavo stood on a NYC street and urged US soldiers to disobey orders and incite violence,” the state department said on X. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The US revoked Colombian President Gustavo Petro's visa.
Petro urged US soldiers to disobey Trump's orders at a protest.
The US cited Petro's "incendiary actions" as the reason for the visa revocation.
Petro made the comments at a pro-Palestinian demonstration in New York.
Tensions between the US and Colombia have escalated due to the incident.

clusters.title: Russia has no intention of attacking EU or Nato states, foreign minister says
clusters.neutral_headline: Lavrov Warns of Decisive Response to Aggression

items.title: Russia has no intention of attacking EU or Nato states, foreign minister says
items.standfirst: Sergei Lavrov has been highly critical of Western countries and Israel in his speech at the UN General Assembly.
items.content: Sergei Lavrov has been highly critical of Western countries and Israel in his speech at the UN General Assembly.

items.title: Any aggression against Russia will be met with 'decisive response', Lavrov tells UN
items.standfirst: Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavron on Saturday told the UN General Assembly that his nation doesn't intend to attack Europe but will mount a “decisive response” to any aggression. FRANCE 24's Aidan Stretch reports from Kyiv, where Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Saturday said Ukraine received a US-made Patriot air defence system from Israel a month ago.
items.content: Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavron on Saturday told the UN General Assembly that his nation doesn't intend to attack Europe but will mount a “decisive response” to any aggression. FRANCE 24's Aidan Stretch reports from Kyiv, where Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Saturday said Ukraine received a US-made Patriot air defence system from Israel a month ago.

items.title: Sergei Lavrov warns NATO and EU countries over 'aggression' towards Russia
items.standfirst: Vladimir Putin's top diplomat says Russia has no intention of attacking any NATO or EU member state but warned of a "decisive response" if any "aggression" was directed towards Moscow.
items.content: Vladimir Putin's top diplomat says Russia has no intention of attacking any NATO or EU member state but warned of a "decisive response" if any "aggression" was directed towards Moscow.

items.title: Russia will give ‘decisive response’ if provoked by West, says Lavrov
items.standfirst: The Russian foreign minister made the comment in an address to the United Nations General Assembly on Saturday.
items.content: The Russian foreign minister made the comment in an address to the United Nations General Assembly on Saturday.

items.title: Lavrov warns of ‘decisive response’ to ‘aggression’ as NATO boosts vigilance after drone incidents
items.standfirst: Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov told the UN General Assembly on Saturday that any aggression against his country will be met with a decisive response. His address came as NATO has been considering whether to shoot down Russian aircraft after a series of incursions over several NATO member states.
items.content: Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov told the UN General Assembly on Saturday that any aggression against his country will be met with a decisive response. His address came as NATO has been considering whether to shoot down Russian aircraft after a series of incursions over several NATO member states.

ai_summary: Russian Foreign Minister Lavrov warned of a "decisive response" to aggression.
Lavrov stated Russia has no intention of attacking EU or NATO states.
The warning was made at the UN General Assembly on Saturday.
NATO is considering whether to shoot down Russian aircraft.
Lavrov's comments came amid increased NATO vigilance after drone incidents.

items.title: Germany and Denmark report renewed drone sightings
items.standfirst: The Danish defense ministry said Saturday that “drones have been observed at several of Danish defense facilities” overnight Friday into Saturday. The renewed drone sightings come after there were several drone sightings in the Nordic country earlier this week, with some of them temporarily shutting down Danish airports. Analysis by FRANCE 24 international affairs editor Philip Turle.
items.content: The Danish defense ministry said Saturday that “drones have been observed at several of Danish defense facilities” overnight Friday into Saturday. clusters.title: Assata Shakur, black liberation activist exiled in Cuba, dies at 78
clusters.neutral_headline: Assata Shakur, black liberation activist exiled in Cuba, dies at 78

items.title: Assata Shakur, black liberation activist exiled in Cuba, dies at 78
items.standfirst: She fled to Cuba after being convicted in the killing of a police officer but denied the shooting.
items.content: She fled to Cuba after being convicted in the killing of a police officer but denied the shooting.

items.title: Assata Shakur, an icon of Black liberation who was exiled to Cuba, dies aged 78
items.standfirst: Shakur spent decades exiled after she was convicted of killing a state trooper in 1977 and escaped from prisonOn 25 September, Assata Shakur, a former member of the Black Liberation Army, died aged 78 in Havana, Cuba, according to Cuba’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Cuban officials cited the reason for her death as old age and health conditions. Shakur, a longstanding symbol of resistance and Black liberation, spent several decades exiled in Cuba after she was convicted of killing a New Jersey state trooper in 1977 and escaped from prison.“At approximately 1:15pm on September 25th, my mother, Assata Shakur, took her last earthly breath,” her daughter Kakuya Shakur wrote on Facebook. “Words cannot describe the depth of loss that I’m feeling at this time.” Continue reading...
items.content: Shakur spent decades exiled after she was convicted of killing a state trooper in 1977 and escaped from prisonOn 25 September, Assata Shakur, a former member of the Black Liberation Army, died aged 78 in Havana, Cuba, according to Cuba’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Cuban officials cited the reason for her death as old age and health conditions. Shakur, a longstanding symbol of resistance and Black liberation, spent several decades exiled in Cuba after she was convicted of killing a New Jersey state trooper in 1977 and escaped from prison.“At approximately 1:15pm on September 25th, my mother, Assata Shakur, took her last earthly breath,” her daughter Kakuya Shakur wrote on Facebook. “Words cannot describe the depth of loss that I’m feeling at this time.” Continue reading...

items.title: Assata Shakur, Black Liberation Army member convicted of killing a state trooper, dies at 78
items.standfirst: Black liberation activist and American fugitive Assata Shakur, who escaped to Cuba more than 45 years ago after she was convicted of killing a New Jersey state trooper, died in Havana, the government announced Friday.
items.content: Black liberation activist and American fugitive Assata Shakur, who escaped to Cuba more than 45 years ago after she was convicted of killing a New Jersey state trooper, died in Havana, the government announced Friday.

ai_summary: Assata Shakur, a Black Liberation Army member, died at age 78.
Shakur was exiled in Cuba after being convicted of killing a state trooper.
She spent decades in exile after escaping from prison.
Shakur was a symbol of resistance and Black liberation.
Her daughter confirmed her death on Facebook.

items.title: One year after Israel killed Hassan Nasrallah, a weakened Hezbollah begins to regroup
items.standfirst: A year after Israeli bunker-busting bombs killed Hezbollah’s charismatic leader Hassan Nasrallah in Beirut’s southern suburbs, the Lebanese government is working to disarm the Shiite militant group while Israel says its power has been decimated. But many experts and Hezbollah supporters disagree.
items.content: A year after Israeli bunker-busting bombs killed Hezbollah’s charismatic leader Hassan Nasrallah in Beirut’s southern suburbs, the Lebanese government is working to disarm the Shiite militant group while Israel says its power has been decimated. But many experts and Hezbollah supporters disagree.

items.title: Lebanon: A year after losing its longtime leader Nasrallah, Hezbollah is beginning to regroup
items.standfirst: Hezbollah suffered one blow after another during its most recent war with Israel, culminating in the killing of the militant group's longtime leader, Hassan Nasrallah, in massive Israeli airstrikes on a Beirut suburb. The group was weakened militarily and politically. Many of its opponents declared that its days as a dominant regional and local player were over. But one year later, many of Hezbollah’s supporters, enemies and analysts agree in their assessment: it is regrouping. Analysis by Sami Nader, director of the Levant Institute for Strategic Affairs in Beirut.
items.content: Hezbollah suffered one blow after another during its most recent war with Israel, culminating in the killing of the militant group's longtime leader, Hassan Nasrallah, in massive Israeli airstrikes on a Beirut suburb. The group was weakened militarily and politically. Many of its opponents declared that its days as a dominant regional and local player were over. But one year later, many of Hezbollah’s supporters, enemies and analysts agree in their assessment: it is regrouping. Analysis by Sami Nader, director of the Levant Institute for Strategic Affairs in Beirut.

ai_summary: Hezbollah refuses to disarm one year after Nasrallah's death.
The Lebanese government has backed plans to disarm Hezbollah.
Hezbollah was weakened by its latest war with Israel.
Some experts believe Hezbollah is regrouping.
The killing of Nasrallah occurred in Israeli airstrikes.

items.standfirst: Pete Hegseth summons hundreds of generals and admirals to Virginia to meet and receive address on ‘warrior ethos’US military officials are reportedly bracing for possible firings or demotions after the Trump administration’s Pentagon chief, Pete Hegseth, abruptly summoned hundreds of generals and admirals from around the world to attend a gathering in Virginia in the upcoming days.The event, scheduled for Tuesday at Marine Corps University in Quantico, is expected to feature a short address by Hegseth focused on military standards and the “warrior ethos”, according to the Washington Post.
